title: VC Daily: VCs Double Down on Cancer-Testing Startups
text:
Typically cancer blood-testing companies have sought to identify markers of cancer such as mutations in the DNA tumors shed into the blood. Delfi says its approach looks instead for a more-abundant signal of the disease that requires relatively little sequencing to detect.

Delfi says its tests will be based on "fragmentomes," which represent the aberrant packaging of DNA in cancer cells. Cancer cells divide so rapidly that they can't properly organize themselves before dividing again, Delfi Chief Scientific Officer Nicholas Dracopoli said.

Delfi founder and Chief Executive Victor Velculescu said it is too soon to project what its tests will cost, but he said he aims to make them affordable enough to be used widely in the U.S. and elsewhere.

And now on to the news...

Top News

Cash infusion. Blend Labs Inc., a provider of mortgage and other consumer-lending software to financial institutions, nearly doubled its valuation to $3.3 billion within six months, another example of a fast-moving late-stage fintech deal, WSJ Pro's Yuliya Chernova reports.

* Coatue Management and Tiger Global Management, two of the most active tech investors in both the public and private markets, supplied all of the $300 million in the company's Series G financing, according to Nima Ghamsari, chief executive officer and co-founder of San Francisco-based Blend.

* "Coatue and Tiger frankly wanted to write larger checks," he said, adding that Blend decided to limit the size of the round because it didn't need more capital. The round didn't have room for earlier investors to participate, he said. Mr. Ghamsari said he expects all investors to benefit as Blend uses the new capital to fuel its business and grow.

"I don't want to be slowing down because someone is dilution-sensitive."

—Nima Ghamsari, CEO of San Francisco-based Blend

Visa Abandons Planned Acquisition of Plaid After DOJ Challenge

Visa Inc . abandoned its $5.3 billion planned acquisition of financial-technology firm Plaid Inc. amid a Justice Department antitrust lawsuit that challenged the deal, The Wall Street Journal reports.

Remote-Work Boom During Pandemic Draws Real-Estate Startups

A group of real-estate startups is aiming to cash in on the remote-work phenomenon, WSJ's Konrad Putzier reports. With many corporate offices closed because of the pandemic, many young professionals have left cities like New York and San Francisco for warmer, cheaper places. A number still plan to return after their offices reopen, leaving them reluctant to buy homes or sign long-term apartment leases. That situation is creating fresh demand for furnished housing on a short-term basis, a fast-growing niche that many property startups and their venture-capital backers are rushing to fill.

AI Startup Sees Opportunity Forecasting Consumer Demand

Centricity Inc., a startup that uses artificial intelligence to help companies predict consumer demand for specific products in particular communities, is expected to raise $10 million in new venture-capital money this year, CIO Journal's Sara Castellanos reports.

Industry News

Funds

Israeli firm Glilot Capital Partners launched its first early growth fund with $170 million in commitments. Glilot+ will make post-Series A investments of between $5 million to $20 million per deal in about 15 software and cybersecurity companies. Glilot+ is the firm's fifth fund to date, bringing total assets under management to $500 million.

People

College graduate job search startup Handshake appointed Asif Makhani as the company's new chief technology officer. He was previously director and general manager of Google Images and head of engineering at LinkedIn Learning Solutions. In October, San Francisco-based Handshake raised an $80 million Series D round from investors including GGV Capital , EQT Ventures, Kleiner Perkins , Lightspeed Venture Partners , Spark Capital and True Ventures .

Cloud security startup Lacework, which last week secured a $525 million growth round, named Mike Staiger to the post of chief financial officer. He was previously CFO of ThousandEyes. Sutter Hill Ventures , Altimeter Capital, D1 Capital Partners, Coatue and Dragoneer Investment Group provided last week's funding round.

Big-data startup Alation Inc. appointed Tracy Eiler as chief marketing officer. She was most recently CMO of InsideView . Redwood City, Calif.-based Alation is backed by Sapphire Ventures , Salesforce Ventures , Costanoa Ventures , Data Collective, Harmony Partners and Icon Ventures.

Exits

Threat detection startup Huntress Labs Inc. acquired endpoint detection and response technology from San Antonio, Texas-based Level Effect. Terms weren't disclosed. In February 2020, Ellicott City, Md.-based Huntress raised an $18 million Series A round led by ForgePoint Capital Management.

New Money

Checkout.com, a London-based transaction processor for internet companies, closed a $450 million Series C round at a valuation of $15 billion. Tiger Global Management led the investment, which included additional support from Greenoaks Capital, Insight Partners, DST Global, Coatue Management, Blossom Capital, Endeavor Catalyst and GIC.

Rapyd, a London-based startup offering digital payments software, collected $300 million in Series D financing led by Coatue. New investors Spark Capital, Avid Ventures, FJ Labs and Latitude also contributed to the round alongside returning backers General Catalyst, Oak FT, Tiger Global, Target Global, Durable Capital, Tal Capital and Entrée Capital.

Cockroach Labs, a New York-based distributed SQL database provider, picked up a $160 million investment led by Altimeter Capital that gives the company a valuation of $2 billion. New investors Greenoaks and Lone Pine also participated in the round, along with existing backers Benchmark, BOND, FirstMark, GV, Index Ventures and Tiger Global.

Prodigy Education, a math tutoring startup, landed 159 million Canadian dollars ($125 million) in Series B funding. TPG Growth led the investment, with Principal Jacqui Hawwa joining the company's board. Canadian Business Growth Fund also participated in the round.

Workato Inc., a Mountain View, Calif.-based enterprise automation platform, secured $110 million in Series D financing valuing the company at $1.7 billion. Altimeter Capital and Insight Partners led the round, which included participation from Redpoint Ventures and Battery Ventures.

Curve, a London-based banking platform that allows customers to consolidate multiple cards into one smart card and app, snagged $95 million in Series C funding. IDC Ventures, Fuel Venture Capital and Vulcan Capital led the round, with additional contributions from OneMain Financial and Novum Capital.

Clark, a Germany-based digital insurance manager, nabbed €69 million ($84.1 million) in Series C funding. Tencent led the round, and was joined by Portag3 Ventures, White Star Capital and Yabeo.

M-Files Inc., an Austin, Texas- and Finland-based information management platform, grabbed an $80 million strategic investment. Bregal Milestone led the funding, which saw participation from Partech, Tesi and Draper Esprit .

Open Farm, a Toronto-based pet food brand, raised more than 80 million Canadian dollars ($63 million) in new funding. General Atlantic led the investment, which included participation from Encore Consumer Capital.

Jobber, a Canadian provider of home service management software, secured a $60 million growth equity round. Summit Partners led the investment, with additional support from Omers Ventures , Version One Ventures and Tech Pioneers Fund. Colin Mistele, principal at Summit Partners, joined the board.

Landing, a San Francisco-based startup offering fully-finished apartments and services, fetched $45 million in Series B funding, alongside a $55 million debt facility. Foundry Group led the Series B round, with participation from Greycroft and Maveron.

Relay Payments, an Atlanta-based electronic payment network in the transportation, logistics and supply chain industries, raised $43 million in funding. Addition led the round, which saw support from Ribbit Capital and Spark Capital.

airSlate Inc., a Boston-based business automation services provider, completed a $40 million funding round. Morgan Stanley Expansion Capital led the investment, with Pete Chung joining the company's board. General Catalyst and HighSage Ventures also participated in the round.

Tech News

* New GM electric-truck business targets delivery market

* Zoom aims to raise $1.5 billion through stock offering

* Samsung seizes smartphone initiative as sanctions hobble Huawei

* SolarWinds discloses earlier evidence of hack

Around the Web

* Gig workers and unions sue in California Supreme Court to have Prop 22 overturned (Washington Post)

* Look, up in the sky—it's a flying Cadillac! GM unveils futuristic vehicle (Reuters)
